p: Dengue viruses (DENV) are members of the Flaviviridae family and present four serotypes (DENV‐1, DENV‐2, DENV‐3, and DENV‐4) ( 2). They are capable of causing classic dengue fever (DF), dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF), and dengue shock syndrome (DSS) and are the leading cause of child death in some countries ( 3). Commonly, DF presents only mildly symptoms, including fever, headache, rash, abdominal pain, and nausea. Basically, after inoculation by the mosquito, local dendritic cells and macrophages are infected, followed by virus entry into the bloodstream and infection of other blood cells. This context results in leukopenia and thrombocytopenia in laboratory tests of patients ( 4, 5). After some days, humoral and cellular immune responses are efficiently mounted against the virus, eliminating infection. This humoral response produces protective serotype‐specific antibodies. These antibodies cross‐react, but do not neutralize other virus subtypes, failing to offer protective immunity against them ( 6).
